etymologies: late 15th century: from Old French mutuel, from Latin mutuus ‘mutual, borrowed’; related to mutare ‘to change’

notes.text: Some traditionalists consider using mutual to mean ‘common to two or more people’ (a mutual friend; a mutual interest) to be incorrect, holding that a sense of reciprocity is necessary (mutual respect; mutual need). The use they object to has a long and respectable history, however, being first recorded in Shakespeare and appearing in the writing of Sir Walter Scott, George Eliot, and, most famously, as the title of Dickens's novel Our Mutual Friend. It is now generally accepted as part of standard English

definitions: (of a feeling or action) experienced or done by each of two or more parties toward the other or others

examples.text: a partnership based on mutual respect and understanding
my father hated him from the start and the feeling was mutual

shortDefinitions: experienced or done by each of two or more parties towards other or others

definitions: (of two or more people) having the same specified relationship to each other

examples.text: they were mutual beneficiaries of the settlement

definitions: held in common by two or more parties

examples.text: we were introduced by a mutual friend

shortDefinitions: held in common by two or more parties

definitions: denoting an insurance company or other corporate organization owned by its members and dividing some or all of its profits between them

examples.text: the world's oldest mutual insurance company

shortDefinitions: referring to building society owned by its members
